Updated IRM 5.7.7.4.1(6) to incorporate Collection Interim Guidance Memorandum SBSE-05-0814- 0022, Interim Guidance for Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Protest Cases and Form 843, Claim for Refund and Request for Abatement, Processing by Advisory, which provides guidance on Advisory actions upon receipt of a claim when Appeals has already made a determination.
Updated IRM 5.7.7.4.6(1) to provide guidance to research ATFR to determine if Appeals made a prior determination on the TFRP after receipt of a Letter 1153 protest.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 5.7.7 dated August 2, 2013. This IRM incorporates Collection Interim Guidance Memorandum SBSE-05-0814-0022, Interim Guidance for Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Protest Cases and Form 843, Claim for Refund and Request for Abatement, Processing by Advisory.
Small Business/Self-Employed Collection Employees

Application and Refund Claims 5.7.7
and Refund Claims
) This chapter provides guidance to Collection employees on Trust Fund Recovery Penalty payment application and refund claims. (

) Even after assessment of the TFRP, revenue officers may still secure an in- stallment agreement for an in-business BMF trust fund taxpayer. Once the agreement has been approved by the group manager, the revenue officer the group manager will give consideration to withholding collection on the TFRP balance due accounts. (

) Determine the potential success of the installment agreement (are there income and assets of the in-business taxpayer that could full pay the and consider: a. What is the collection potential of the TFRP balance due accounts? b. Is collection of the TFRP balance due accounts in jeopardy? c. Will a Notice of Federal Tax Lien be filed? d. If no lien will be filed, will the person held responsible provide a bond, other collateral, or adequate protection (IRM

, Collateral and Security Type Collateral)? Example: Adequate protection includes otherwise unencumbered assets of the business currently secured by a federal tax lien for the same periods and having sufficient equity from which the BMF tax (non-trust and fund) can be paid in full. (
) When the decision is made to stay collection of the TFRP, the revenue will follow the procedures in IRM
), Trust Fund Recovery and Installment Agreements. (
) A payment received on a responsible person’s account prior to assessment the TFRP will be applied using Form

in the Form Number/MFT block. b. Enter the dollar amount of the payment next to the TC

payments. Note: DPC information can be found in Document
, ADP and IDRS tion. DPC
is normally used; however, use DPC

if the payment is for manually monitored pre-assessed installment agreement, or use another propriate code based on the type of payment being made. d. Enter in the Remarks section “Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Pending” followed by the name and TIN of the business and the approximate as- sessment date so the payment can be properly identified. e. Submit the payment with the posting voucher on Form
f. Retain a copy of Form
in the TFRP case file.

A payment received on a responsible person’s account prior to assessment of the TFRP will be applied using Form 3244, Payment Posting Voucher:
(04-13-2006) Pre-Assessment Payment

DPC information can be found in Document 6209, ADP and IDRS Informa- tion. DPC 99 is normally used; however, use DPC 10 if the payment is for a manually monitored pre-assessed installment agreement, or use another propriate code based on the type of payment being made.
Trust Fund (
) After the TFRP has been assessed, payments/credits may be applied to the underlying trust fund liability, as well as to the TFRP assessment(s). of (

) Compliance Services Collection Operations (CSCO) is responsible for referencing already posted payments and credits among related BMF and Due TFRP accounts, as well as computing and cross-referencing interest on accounts. IRM
, Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP), contains the operating instructions for these activities. CSCO does not decide where to apply the incoming remittances. (
) Unless interest was also fully paid by the underlying trust fund taxpayer, the TFRP taxpayer will still be liable for the interest on the TFRP assessment. (
) Section
of the Taxpayer Bill of Rights
(TBOR
) expanded IRC to add subsection (e)(
) which provides for certain disclosures to persons have been assessed the TFRP pursuant to IRC
IRC
) for disclosure to each person who has been assessed the TFRP, certain limited information regarding other persons assessed the penalty for the underlying tax. See IRM
, Disclosure of Trust Fund Recovery Payment Information, for additional information on what information can and cannot be disclosed, as well as the method of disclosure. (
) The taxpayer should submit a claim for refund involving a TFRP on Form Claim for Refund and Request for Abatement. See IRM
, Collection - IRC

(c), for information on the additional actions the must take and the required time frames in order for the Service to be to withhold collection action. The taxpayer must submit a separate Form for each period the taxpayer wants considered for refund and abatement. (
) In order to file a claim for refund of a TFRP, for each applicable tax period taxpayer must pay the portion of penalty attributable to either: (cid:
) One employee if the TFRP is based on employment taxes (cid:
) One transaction if the claim relates to a TFRP for excise taxes Note: If the taxpayer files suit the government will place the unpaid portion of TFRP before the court by means of counterclaim. (
) Generally, the Service will consider TFRP claims for refund (and for related abatement of unpaid TFRP portions) if they are filed within two years after date the required payment was made. (
) The Advisory office where the claimant resides should work the claim.
After the TFRP has been assessed, payments/credits may be applied to the underlying trust fund liability, as well as to the TFRP assessment(s).
Unless interest was also fully paid by the underlying trust fund taxpayer, the TFRP taxpayer will still be liable for the interest on the TFRP assessment.
In order to file a claim for refund of a TFRP, for each applicable tax period taxpayer must pay the portion of penalty attributable to either:
(cid:129) One employee if the TFRP is based on employment taxes (cid:129) One transaction if the claim relates to a TFRP for excise
Note: If the taxpayer files suit the government will place the unpaid portion of the TFRP before the court by means of counterclaim.
Generally, the Service will consider TFRP claims for refund (and for related abatement of unpaid TFRP portions) if they are filed within two years after the date the required payment was made.

As part of Collection’s ordinary consideration of a case, the revenue officer may make history entries in ICS or ATFR regarding the original basis for TFRP assess- ment as the Form 843 has not been denied and no appeal has been filed.
Date stamp Form
upon receipt. Advisory should complete the initial review of the claim within
days of receipt. Form

claims must be processed promptly since the taxpayer may file suit if the claim is not acted upon within six months of filing. Advisory should issue interim status letters as needed to avoid unnecessary litigation. When circumstances dictate, the employee should use problem solving and negotiation techniques, and in so doing consider the applicant’s perspective when analyzing the claim. Open an ICS NF Other Investigation (OI) to control the claim no later than
calendar days of receipt in the group. Check ICS for any prior claims or
Note: All actions taken on the claim will be documented in the ICS history including, but not limited to:
(cid:
) Results of research and reviews (cid:
) Dates any correspondence was initiated to the claimant (cid:
) Deadlines established for the claimant, that the claimant was advised of consequences and that follow-up deadlines were established (cid:
) Determinations and reasons for the determinations
Note: If a prior claim was rejected and the current claim provides no additional in

formation, notify the claimant in writing that the new claim cannot be considered. Explain that the right to bring suit was lost if not exercised in a timely fashion after denial of the earlier claim. Contact Area Counsel for any questionable issues involving the taxpayer’s right to bring suit. Update the ICS history with the date the claimant was notified and the reason(s) for not being considered.
) Review transcripts to identify payments or credits made within two years of filing of Form
; these are the only amounts that may be considered for refund (see IRC

(a)). Note: If the taxpayer is determined to be not responsible for the TFRP, payments made beyond this two year period may not be refunded to the taxpayer but must be transferred to excess collections (see IRM
, Preparation Form
for an Adjustment or Abatement). (
) Review Form
for processability and to identify the issues involved. Generally, a Form

claim is processable if the taxpayer and tax periods be identified, the required payment has been made, and there is some type of explanation provided. If the form is not processable: a. Address the basic issues of the case, even if the claim is not processable. b. Prepare a letter to the claimant outlining and explaining the defects, needed corrections, and the additional information needed. c. Include a reasonable time frame for response (generally
days). d. Close the control with no further action if no response is received. Note: In some cases, an incomplete claim may be considered a valid claim. In such cases, issue a formal denial (IRM
, Claim Denied - IRC
(c) Not Applicable, and IRM
, Claim Denied - IRC
(c) Ap- plicable) advising the taxpayer of his or her right to file suit. Consult Area Counsel to resolve uncertainties as to the proper response. (
) Retrieve the TFRP file(s) and review them to determine: (cid:
) If any basic procedural defects exist (cid:
) If sufficient file information exists to evaluate and respond to the issues raised (cid:

), IRC
(c) (IRM
, Third- Party Interviews and Third-Party Contact Considerations), and IRC
(a) (IRM

, Procedures for Summonses Issued to Investigate Liabili- ties for the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty) and actions were documented in ICS and/or ATFR. If necessary, consult your manager. Note: If the TFRP balance due or the employer balance due accounts are to a revenue officer, identify that person and coordinate all actions and minations with him/her. (

) If an Appeals determination was already made in regard to the TFRP at issue (whether in the form of Letter

protest, claim, doubt as to liability offer in compromise, etc.), neither Advisory nor field collection employees can reverse the prior determination made by Appeals. Only Appeals can reverse such a determination. Therefore, the claim will be forwarded to Appeals without con- sideration by Advisory. a. If Appeals determines during initial review that the issue raised is the same as in the previous Appeals determination, Appeals will retain jurisdic- tion of the claim.
Application and Refund Claims 5.7.7

b. If Appeals determines during initial review the issue raised in the new claim is different from the issue raised in the previous Appeals tion, Appeals will close the claim as a premature referral and return it to Advisory. c. Advisory will consider the claim, addressing only new issues, and make determination. Advisory has the authority to make a claim determination for new issues raised only after Appeals has confirmed there has been prior Appeals determination on the specific issue(s) raised. Advisory’s termination is not considered a reversal of Appeals prior determination it pertains to a new issue(s). (
) If the TFRP clearly cannot be substantiated, Advisory should follow the dures in IRM
, Claim Accepted, for accepting the claim and Form
to abate the assessment. Consult Area Counsel if there are questions over the validity of the assessment. (
) Possible actions by Advisory include: (cid:
) Acceptance of the claim (IRM
, Claim Accepted) (cid:
) Use of Fast Track Mediation (IRM
), Appealing the Proposed sessment) (cid:
) Denial of the claim (IRM

(c) Not cable, or

(c) Applicable) (cid:

, Referral to Appeals and Fast Track Mediation (FTM)) (
) When a determination is made on the claim (formal or informal), advise the taxpayer in the closing correspondence of any funds moved to excess tions due to IRC

) If the information in the file is not sufficient to support assertion and/or if any procedural defects are identified, the Advisory employee will determine the need for field group assistance and, if necessary, issue a Courtesy tion no later than

calendars days after completion of the initial review to secure additional documentation. Note: Some procedural defects may invalidate the assessment. Consult Area Counsel if there are questions over the validity of the assessment. (

If Appeals determines during initial review the issue raised in the new claim is different from the issue raised in the previous Appeals determina

tion, Appeals will close the claim as a premature referral and return it to Advisory. Advisory will consider the claim, addressing only new issues, and make a determination. Advisory has the authority to make a claim determination for new issues raised only after Appeals has confirmed there has been prior Appeals determination on the specific issue(s) raised. Advisory’s de
termination is not considered a reversal of Appeals prior determination as it pertains to a new issue(s).

If the TFRP file(s) cannot be located and/or reconstructed, consult with Counsel to make a determination as to whether the claim should be (IRM 5.7.7.4.3, Claim Accepted) or if the claim should be denied (IRM 5.7.7.4.4, Claim Denied - IRC 6672(c) Not Applicable, and IRM 5.7.7.4.5, Claim Denied - IRC 6672(c) Applicable) based upon the hazards of litigation for defending the Service’s position if the taxpayer later files suit.

The Service is not required to concede a case solely because the case file cannot be located or has been destroyed. If this situation arises, consult with local counsel in deciding whether or not to concede the case.
local counsel in deciding whether or not to concede the case. (

) If Advisory does not fully abate the TFRP, determine if a referral to Appeals appropriate. and Reminder: Neither Advisory nor field collection employees can reverse a prior termination made by Appeals. Only Appeals can reverse such a determination. (
) Situations where referral to Appeals may be appropriate include the (cid:
) Appeals has already made a determination on the case. (cid:
) It is not clear the claimant was given adequate access to the appeal process (or if it is clear they did not), and a determination by Appeals be beneficial to the government’s position. (cid:
) Other situations in which it is deemed advisable, generally to ensure or strengthen the Government’s position in potential litigation. (
) If referral to Appeals is appropriate, the revenue officer will: a. Update the TFRP file. b. Prepare and mail Letter
(DO) to the claimant. c. Return the files to Advisory to be forwarded to Appeals. (
) Advisors should consider FTM as an option since taxpayers may also use FTM process for Form
claims that are being rejected. The advisor may advise the taxpayer of FTM at any time during the review process. If FTM not been discussed prior to issuance of the rejection letter (see IRM
, Claim Denied - IRC
(c) Not Applicable, and

(c) Applicable), include Publication

, Fast Track Mediation - A Process for Prompt Resolution of Tax Issues, with the letter denying the Note: Remind taxpayers that even if the IRS agrees to use FTM, the time for formally appealing the denial and filing suit still apply. (

) The prohibition against ex parte communications between Appeals and originating function employees does not apply to FTM because the Appeals employees are not acting in their traditional Appeals settlement role. Ex parte communications, such as a private caucus between the Appeals mediator and Collection employees during the course of the mediation is permissible under the ex parte communication rules. Part of the role of mediator is to meet separately with each side in order to bring about a tion. (

) Justification: For abatements, the reasons specified must address respon- sibility and willfulness. “The taxpayer is not liable” is not sufficient justification.
